newsitem.title: UK: British gilts power to new record.
newsitem.headline: British gilts power to new record.

text.p: Gilt futures shot higher on Friday, reversing sessions of underperformance while core European bonds could post only modest gains, dealers said.
The December gilt future was trading at 108-31 at 0930 GMT, up 16/32 on the day and just below a 109-02 contract high set earlier in the session.
The gilt/Bund spread shot in to 171 basis points from 177 late on Thursday. At times this week, it has widened beyond 180.
"Gilts have underperformed over the past couple of weeks and are playing catch-up," said Jonathan York, futures broker at Cater Allen. "There's quite a bit of upside here."
At the short end of the market, short sterling futures also found a new lease of life.
The December contract gained three basis points to 94.04, the March future rose four to 93.90 and the June contract leapt seven basis points to 93.66.
Looking further out, 1998 and 1999 contracts leapt by 14 or 15 basis points. But analysts said this did not reflect a long-term reappraisal of British interest rate prospects.
"Short sterling has purely been dragged up by the gilt," said Peter Osler, economist at GNI. "I think it has gone a bit too far."
Economists said gilts had suffered in the aftermath of last weekend's meeting of European Union leaders in Ireland.
EU officials said agreement on a stability pact and a new exchange rate mechanism meant European Economic and Monetary Union was bang on target for its intended start date in January 1999.

That prompted a wave of convergence trades by Europe's more peripheral bond markets over Bunds. But the UK's opt-out clause from a single currency left gilts outside the convergence plays prompted by pro-EMU sentiment.
Convergence trades aim to profit from the narrowing of the differences between currencies as EMU approaches.

Analysts said Friday's gilt rally showed investors are saying enough is enough and reappraising the fundamental value the gilt market offers. "It's about time," said Steve Scott, gilts analyst at Kleinwort Benson.
"There was always going to be support for gilts above 180. The intraday peak of 183 earlier this week probably lured buyers back in," Scott said.
The relative moves by the Swedish and Spanish bond markets had prompted investors to re-evaluate, he said.
"There's probably another 10 basis points of narrowing for gilts (over Bunds) in the medium-term."
